tweets.content:
The @ArcadiaFi hack resulted in over $2M in losses due to a long chain of an arbitrary call. 

The attacker exploited the rebalancing process by crafting arbitrary swap data for rebalancing. This allowed the rebalancer to make calls to any account, which could then re-enter the rebalancer and trigger further full arbitrary calls to victim accounts. This call chain lets the attacker withdraw more assets while repaying less.

Specifically, `Rebalancer.executeAction` is only callable by an Account, and `Account.flashAction` is only callable by the Rebalancer. By chaining `Rebalancer.rebalance(controlled_data)` â†’ `Account1.flashAction(partially controlled_data)` â†’ `Rebalancer.executeAction(controlled_data)` â†’ `Account2.flashAction(full controlled_data)`, the attacker was able to pass arbitrary calldata to `Account2.flashAction`.

`flashAction` accepts an array of debt and underlying assets, which are meant to be controlled by the rebalancer. Once the attacker gained control over the calldata, they could specify fewer debt assets while withdrawing all assets from the accountâ€”repaying only one debt but taking the full balance.

app.blocksec.com/explorer/txâ€¦

tweets.content:
There might be some confusion regarding why we are still using 400ms blocks - like @megaeth_labs, we support something similar to Mini-block. The sequencer provides a Geyser / Yellowstone endpoint that streams processed transactions out. Verifiers of our chain operate on shreds (sets of transactions), instead of blocks. So the block, in terms of our chain, is purely a measure for chaining the blockchain. 

Beyond compatibility with Solana, another reason we don't build a <400ms block is due to pre-execution. If block time is short, one can DoS the chain by sending transactions depending on block time, making all pre-executions for those transactions invalid under congestion (tx takes longer time to be consumed by the sequencer).

tweets.content:
good example of how auditors and *hackers* think differently:

- threat model: inputs are generated by associated ix builder, so minimal checks is needed on chain. there is not attacking surface in this senario
- svm: if the unsafe code fuck up, invalid memory access only leads to early termination
- safety v.s. security: this code it totally secure, but not safe. you can crash it but you cannot exploit it (thanks to svm)

i do sympathize devs wasting time reading LOWs and MEDIUMs in their audit report

tweets.content:
Correct root cause: there is a transfer function in fourmeme that allows moving unlaunched untransferable tokens to any address. By moving tokens to the predicted LP address, the hacker can frontrun launch tx with an add-liquidity tx for that LP without transferring anything. Then, it can bundle a sell tx afterwards to profit by sandwiching that launch tx.

No other bot can do that because they would have to transfer the untransferable tokens first to LP while the hacker circumvented untransferable restriction. 

Private RPC would likely reduce the loss or completely circumvent this hack.

tweets.content:
Our pentest AI agent found an RCE 0day in Apache Arrow and RisingWave. The vulnerability is simple, but this might be the first 0day found then exploited by an AI agent. 

The vulnerability was reported 4 months ago but was never fixed, so here is the disclosure of the vulnerability and how the agent found it: 

RisingWave & some databases based on Arrow allow every user, including read-only users, to create UDFs. The UDFs are then passed to `arrow-udf` package (used by Arrow) for execution. The package creates a sandbox via sub-interpreters for Python code to execute, with flags like allow_exec=0 and allow_threads=0 (github.com/arrow-udf/arrow-uâ€¦) to disallow imports and `os` package. 

However, Pythonâ€™s sub-interpreters are not designed as true sandboxes; even with these flags, the object hierarchy remains accessible. By leveraging Pythonâ€™s introspection features, we can enumerate every subclass of objects and inspect each subclassâ€™s __globals__ dictionary, thereby finding the `sys` module. Once sys is found, it can be used to retrieve `os` from `sys.modules`, circumventing any restrictions the sandbox might impose. 

During pentesting, our agent found a hardcoded Risingwave credential leaked in the frontend, and then connected to the database. The credential has read-only privilege and can only view limited tables with no valuable information. The agent then searched the RisingWave document and found the UDF feature. Initially, it searched and tried to use common sandbox escape code inside UDF, but none worked. Then, it used these code as seeds and started mutating (fuzzing). Finally, it gets access to `os` package. Exploiting this RCE, the pentest agent gained full control over target GCP+AWS via information in the database and metadata endpoint. All of these steps were conducted in ~36 hours with some human interventions.

tweets.content:
Let's talk about how we @solayer_labs push 1M TPS (~5Gbps) state sync efficiently to thousands of nodes (~10Tbps). We used the same concept as Solana, with little modification.

We use a sharded turbine architecture combined with PCDN. Each shred is pushed to one of the shards managed by the current leader. These shreds are then compressed and broadcast via dark fibers to underlying replicas managed by the current leader in multiple regions.

Multiple layers of replicas can exist, as in Solana. Finally, the shred gets to the verifiers. Note that at this stage, the bandwidth now is significantly (^n) higher than just that of the current leader itself. Hundreds of verifiers then serve state sync requests from normal users.

Bandwidth is very expensive. We leverage PCDN to reduce costs for state subscribers who do not want low latency (do not stake). State syncs and historical states are served via random folks interested in contributing storage and bandwidth, and the subscribers can fetch asynchronously in parallel.
tweets.author: shoucccc

tweets.content:
1inch market maker @trustedvolumes got hacked for over $4.5M and a few smaller MMs got hacked for $0.5M yesterday. 

The root cause is that 1inch calls MM contractâ€™s resolveOrders function to get funds to its settlement contract. Most bots only checked the msg.sender = settlement contract  - and unfortunately there was an arbitrary call vulnerability in settlement contract. Thus the hacker could forge resolveOrders call and drain MM contracts. 

The funny thing is the hacker incorrectly transferred half of the stolen funds to the 1inch settlement contract, making the funds available for everyone to grab, and he spent quite sometime to get funds back. We were trying to compete but the hacker got it first unfortunately.

tweets.content:
We @shoucccc @tonykebot found a critical vulnerability in time.fun last week and conducted a hack. The vulnerability allows hackers to steal all trading fees and modify metadata (e.g. change "toly's minute" to "vitalik's minute") of every tokens launched. 

As the issue has been resolved, here is the full disclosure:

time.fun provides each new user with a dedicated wallet to deposit USDC for trading. User's private key is securely stored in a third party provider. But SOL is needed to cover gas fees and time.fun wants a seamless interaction for users, the wallet â€œHW2C...Lo1Hâ€ signs every trade transaction alongside the userâ€™s wallet signature. Surprisingly, this same wallet also owns all tokens launched by time.fun. As it is one of the signers, we can act on behalf of â€œHW2C...Lo1Hâ€ if we can let the backend sign arbitrary data.

We discovered that by forging a token, it was possible to trick the backend into believing it was signing a legitimate transactionâ€”letting us change metadata or withdraw all funds from â€œHW2C...Lo1H.â€ We reached out to the team (through buying 1 minute of their founder on time.fun) meanwhile did a whitehat hack. The team responded and fixed quickly and we returned all the funds.

All backends should never sign transactions coming from the frontend, regardless of how thorough the validation or simulation checks appear. These safeguards can be bypassed by obfuscating transactions or bundling/front-running transactions to alter their semantics.

tweets.content:
Turns out @cz_binance sent the first $TST buy tx to private RPC, but that tx still got leaked somehow. 

CZ's buy tx (bscscan.com/tx/0x84fba4557a3â€¦) set the minimum output to 363,225 TST, while at that block, he can receive up to 365,564 TST (~0.7% slippage). If this tx is not sent to the private RPC, then it can lead to a $200+ profit for the sandwich bot, and the sandwich bot must sandwich it. However, none did and the block builder payment was much lower than $200 at that block, so it is apparent that CZ used private RPC. 

The reason that CZ's buy tx failed was due to someone buying TST ahead of CZ (bscscan.com/tx/0x9b2b3b99536â€¦). Unfortunately, this guy got sandwiched. Block builder prioritized this tx with sandwich txs over CZ's tx because the sandwich bot made $0.2 payments to block builder. If CZ set his gas price to 1.5gwei, his tx would likely be prioritized and succeed. 

The real suspicious thing is why would 0xB2d57876271eA8684e7c521c1265b87703d9A0DA (B1) know CZ is buying $TST in advance. The bot explicitly checked CZ's TST balance (if it succeeds) and attempted to backrun his transaction. Is the private orderflow shared with this bot? Maybe I am retarded and missed something, or I guess only the bot owner/block builder/relay knows.

tweets.author: shoucccc

tweets.content:
I guess folks are not happy with â€œ16B+ TPSâ€ claim. Here are some clarifications - itâ€™s used to show throughput.

16B+ *non-conflicting* transactions with correct pre-execution is around 700GB in our implementation and can be easily handled by sequencer in one second. Sequencer just needs to apply the effects via RDMA.

For conflicting transactions, TPS is much lower than that.
tweets.author: shoucccc

tweets.author: shoucccc

tweets.content:
"Why do you guys do chain now? I thought you guys are restaking projects" Lots of friends ask me this question when I share the paper around.

The answer is, restaking is NEVER our mission. We were,  are, and always target to make blockchain the next generation of internet: Unlimited, Fast, Cheap, and Accessible.

We started from @solana  as SVM has the best parallelization capability and adoption.  

Then we started from restaking (EndoAVS: solayer.org/platform/endoavs) as as we find out that stake-weighted quality of service can HELP prioritize tx. Its also a good starting point to solve the congestion issues of solana and also for us to build up the team and influence.

We also researched many solutions as well, projects like @jito_sol, @bloxroute have their good ways to tackle the solana congestion issue.

But we believe the end game is not further software optimization or competing for block space by paying more. Blockchain should be a public infra like internet: "Unlimited, Fast, Cheap, and Accessible".

@jump_firedancer  reminds us of early @Cisco and we believe that believe that hardware gona be the admission ticket to the end game.

So, here we go:

- World first hardware accelerated chain
- 100+ GBPS network bandwidth
- 1M+ TPS

Testnet soon

tweets.author: shoucccc

tweets.content:
I quit my PhD at UC Berkeley and joined @solayer_labs as a lead engineer to build the next-gen blockchain. Line rate (100Gbps~4Tbps or 16B+ TPS) transaction ingestion and processing have been achieved internally.   

Everyone can play Minecraft, stream 8K videos, and trade at lightspeed fully on Solayer chain. To achieve this, we draw inspiration from @jump_firedancer and offload almost every component of Solana to hardware like SmartNIC and programmable switches.   

All transactions sent to Solayer Chain will first hit the scalable ingress clusters consisting of hundreds to millions of nodes for scrubbing and pre-executions based on probabilistic predictions of future states. All execution snapshots are sent to a sequencer built using Intel Tofino switches and additional FPGA to decide an optimal schedule - most transactions do not require execution at the sequencer. For the remaining conflicting transactions, our sequencer leverages the SOTA scheduling algorithm based on more fine-grained account access patterns collected from pre-execution to re-execute.   

For a simple workload, we can achieve over 16B+ TPS, and for a fully conflicting workload, we can achieve over 890K TPS. In another way of saying, for each second, we can process billions of people transferring USDC and millions of people aping the same memecoin on Raydium.   

Testnet soon.

No one can unstake $M3M3 on the frontend right now. It seems Meteora messed up by hardcoding a low CU budget value.

A real quick fix is:
1. Go to unstake page
2. Right click and "Inspect"
3. Place a breakpoint
4. Unstake, change c value and resume
5. Happy unstake and sell

tweets.content:
Logic flaw! The attacker lurks for 30 days before the attack. 

The staking contract is exploited by staking on behalf of a new account and unstaking by the account that staked 30 days ago. For each iteration, 20000 VSTR were extracted from the contracts.
